docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: So for years New York City health inspectors drove up the cost of restaurant meals with a shakedown racket. I for one, possibly the only one, am sore at the Health Department about this. I want the Health Department to send me back my money.
docs.snippet: LEAD: So for years New York City health inspectors drove up the cost of restaurant meals with a shakedown racket. I for one, possibly the only one, am sore at the Health Department about this. I want the Health Department to send me back my money....

docs.lead_paragraph: OVER the past 10 years culinary bandwagons with such labels as French Nouvelle, New American, California and Natural Food have led many chefs, cooking schools and restaurants to re-evaluate and rejuvinate their thinking, a reconsideration that has resulted in a felicitous dining evolution. Free to borrow here, adapt there, contemporary practitioners of the kitchen arts reshaped classical techniques and ideas, setting great store on the personal rather than on the national, on experiment and surprise rather than on skillful conformity. Not many restaurants in the United States today have remained untouched by these trends. Closer to home, one of the very few places in the county still glorifying traditional French cuisine with fine workmanship is Auberge Argenteuil. County diners yearning for a comfortably familiar French meal with few innovations will find it no better, no more faithfully executed than at this hilltop restaurant.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE delight of dining Japanese style on the Island continues to increase with the latest addition, Umai in Merrick. This attractive restaurant is built on three levels, with the areas divided by the same light wood as the booths, tables and chairs. Construction was recently completed on the open sushi bar, which is presided over by an experienced chef who was previously sequestered in the kitchen. In addition to the beautiful appetizer, entree and deluxe sushi and sashimi assortments on the regular menu, Umai provides a printed a la carte sushi menu, listing most of the varied offerings that are available in individual orders of two to four pieces, starting at $1.80. The large, single rolls of rice, papery black seaweed, fish and vegetables are $1.50 to $3.50. A party of two or more might order a custom array, which is likely to run into more money than the standard assortment, but which comes magnificently presented on a lacquer tray.
docs.snippet: THE delight of dining Japanese style on the Island continues to increase with the latest addition, Umai in Merrick. This attractive restaurant is built on three levels, with the areas divided by the same light wood as the booths, tables and chairs...

docs.lead_paragraph: James L. Bartlett 3d, president of Cuisine Magazine, said yesterday (one day after the magazine filed in Chapter 11) that CBS Inc., with which it has been having acquistion discusions, had made a formal offer that will be accepted this week by its owner, the Forum Communications Corporation of Santa Barbara. There were no details given on the offer.

docs.abstract: Stephanie Lyness reviews Gilt Moroccan Steakhouse and Lounge in New Haven (Metropolitan/Connecticut). Photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WITH spring temperatures regularly hitting the 70s, one of the best places to eat in downtown New Haven is the roof deck at 266 College Street. Until this year, that would have been Bespoke, a contemporary Mediterranean restaurant. But this spring, you'll be eating mezze at its new incarnation, Gilt Moroccan Steakhouse and Lounge. Gilt's chef and owner, Lauren Kendzierski, bought Bespoke in 2010 from New Haven restaurateurs Arturo and Suzette Franco-Comacho. She reopened it in February as Gilt, serving what she described, in a recent phone conversation, as modern Moroccan cuisine.
docs.snippet: Gilt Moroccan Steakhouse and Lounge, which opened in February, has a menu that mixes modern Moroccan fare with a some traditional steakhouse offerings....

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Flying commercial airlines need not be a culinary bust as you imply in ''Nibbling Away at the Cost of Airline Food'' (Jan. 26). You should have included Milwaukee-based Midwest Express Airlines as a wonderful exception to the skimping. Midwest Express spends over $10 on, yes, delicious meals served on cloth tablecloths with complimentary wine. All topped off with warm chocolate cookies.

byline.original: BY CRAIG R. WHITNEY; Craig R. Whitney, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times, was chief of the Times bureau in Bonn for four years

docs.lead_paragraph: What makes a great restaurant is hard work: so much work that no effort is visible at all. At the Auberge de l'Ill in Illhaeusern, in Alsace, this art is elevated to perfection. As the Guide Michelin says, it is ''une des meilleures tables, vaut le voyage'' - it's worth a special trip just to go there, as I told my daughter, Alexandra, when she was 9 years old. She asked then why her mother and I were going to leave her and her brother, Stefan, in Bonn with their grandmother for three days because we were going to Alsace. ''You're going all that way just to eat?'' she asked.

byline.original: By MARIAN BURROS; Marian Burros writes about food for The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Next to muted earth tones, wide open spaces, sunlight and crystal skies, Santa Fe is admired for its artists and art galleries and for its opera season, which continues this year until Aug. 23. Soon it may be almost as well known for its new Southwestern cooking and the variety of its lodgings. Changes in the worlds of food and innkeeping are beginning to happen in Santa Fe. Not that there has been a shortage of places to stay or eat in this charming, somewhat mystical city 7,000 feet above sea level. The main industry is, after all, tourism. But it is not the usual places to dine or sleep that are of real interest. Many of the hotels are quite ordinary. The food in the best known restaurants is usually not authentic Southwestern cuisine.
